content.1: Here you can view and export the current configuration information, or export and import it to another PocketBase environment.

content.1: Returns all data in the "{ tableName }" table, and supports paging query, sorting and filtering
Query a "{ tableName }" table data based on ID
Add a new "{ tableName }" table data
Update a "{ tableName }" table data based on ID
Delete a piece of "{ tableName }" table data based on ID
Subscribe to real-time changes to the "{ tableName }" table via Server Sent Events (SSE)

batchApi.name: Unified addition, deletion, modification and query/POST

content.1: Implemented in a single request: create/update/modify/delete multiple "{ tableName }" table records, and support batch processing and transactions
Query the list of "identity authorization methods" supported by the server
Use email or other fields to combine the password and finally initiate a verification authorization request
Authenticates using an OAuth2 provider and returns a new authentication token and record data
Authenticate using one-time password (OTP)
Create a new authorization token for an already authorized data request
Verify that the user account is valid, for example by sending an email
Send a user password reset request, for example by sending an email
If the user changes the account email address by himself, he needs to verify it through this interface, for example, by sending an email.

content.1: Enter your email address and we'll send you a 'link to reset your password'
content.2: The email has been tried to be sent to '{email}'. If it is not received, it means: 1. The user's mailbox does not exist. 2. It has been collected in the email recycle bin.

content.1: Welcome to PocketBase

When PocketBase is deployed on a platform such as Fly, or accessed through a proxy such as NGINX, requests from different users will come from the same IP address (i.e. the IP of the proxy connected to your PocketBase application).
content.2: In this case, to get the actual user IP (for rate limiting, logging, etc.), you need to configure your proxy correctly and list the following trusted headers that PocketBase can use to extract the user IP.
content.3: When using such a proxy, to prevent spoofing, it is recommended
content.4: Use headers that can only be controlled by the proxy and cannot be set manually by the user
content.5: Make sure the PocketBase server is only accessible through a proxy
content.6: If PocketBase is not deployed behind a proxy, you can clear the header information fields
content.7: A comma separated list of titles, e.g.

tip.1: Configured proxy headers do not match detected ones
tip.2: In some cases, the proxy server may return multiple IP addresses in the HTTP header, usually these IP addresses are arranged in order from the most remote to the most recent. In this case, the rightmost IP address is usually the client's actual IP address and is therefore considered the most reliable or "more trustworthy". However, this is not a hard and fast rule as different proxy servers may have different implementations.
tip.3: The IP on the far left
tip.4: The IP on the far right

content.1: Rate limit label format
content.2: Rate limiting rules are parsed in the following order (stopping on first match)
content.3: If multiple rules have the same label but target different user audiences (e.g. 'guest' vs. 'auth'), only the matching audience rule will be considered
content.4: Rate limit labels can be in one of the following formats:

action.hideEditControl: Hidden data creation and editing entrance

smtp.title: SMTP configuration

content.1: When turned off, PocketBase will use the unix "sendmail" command to send email (this feature is no longer available). In order to ensure that the mail is sent, please also configure the SMTP mail server yourself
content.2: Some SMTP servers, such as Gmail SMTP-relay, require an appropriate domain name in the initial EHLO/HELO exchange to identify the server sending the email. Using 'localhost' or an invalid domain name may cause the SMTP server to refuse the connection, as they usually require verification of the server sending the mail to prevent abuse and spam.

smtp.ehloOrHeloDomain: Domain name provided to the mail server for verification (EHLO/HELO)

content.1: Use local file system by default to store uploaded files
content.2: If you have limited disk space, you can choose to enable S3 Object Storage to store your files in cloud storage
content.3: If files uploaded by users exist locally, please manually transfer them to the new object storage
content.4: There are many command line tools that can help you, such as:

action.s3Enable: Enable and configure S3 object storage

content.1: Data backup & recovery
content.3: Please note that during the backup, other concurrent write requests may fail because the database will be temporarily 'locked' (usually happens during ZIP generation)
content.4: If you are using S3 storage to upload collection files, you will need to back them up separately as they are not stored locally and will not be included in the final backup!
content.5: The input content needs to carry the “.zip” suffix, and the name can only contain numbers, English, underscores, and minus signs.
content.7: Adopt UTC time zone and support simpler CORN expression👉

action.moreBackupOption: Automatic backup / automatic upload to S3 storage
action.backupToS3: Automatically upload backup files to S3 storage
